titleInfo.title: PROVIDING FOR CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 1259, VA ACCOUNTABILITY FIRST ACT OF 2017; PROVIDING FOR CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 1367, IMPROVING AUTHORITY OF SECRETARY OF VETERANS AFFAIRS TO HIRE AND RETAIN...

extension.searchTitle: PROVIDING FOR CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 1259, VA ACCOUNTABILITY FIRST ACT OF 2017; PROVIDING FOR CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 1367, IMPROVING AUTHORITY OF SECRETARY OF VETERANS AFFAIRS TO HIRE AND RETAIN...; Congressional Record Vol. 163, No. 46

congVote.result: So the previous question was ordered.
congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: Improving the authority of the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to hire and retain physicians and other employees of the Department of Veterans Affairs
Improving the authority of the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to hire and retain physicians and other employees of the Department of Veterans Affairs
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House passed H.R. 1259, to amend title 38, United States Code, to provide for the removal or demotion of employees of the Department of Veterans Affairs based on performance or misconduct, by a recorded vote of 237 ayes to 178 noes, Roll No. 168.<P/>Rejected the Kihuen motion to recommit the bill to the Committee on Veterans' Affairs with instructions to report the same back to the House forthwith with amendments, by a recorded vote of 189 ayes to 229 noes, Roll No. 167.<P/>Pursuant to the Rule, an amendment in the nature of a substitute consisting of the text of Rules Committee Print 115-7 shall be considered as an original bill for the purpose of amendment under the five-minute rule.<P/>Walz amendment (No. 2 printed in part A of H. Rept. 115-39) that sought to grant the VA Secretary improved authorities to hold VA senior executives and employees accountable, protects employees' constitutionally guaranteed due process rights, and protects employees' collective bargaining rights under federal law (by a recorded vote of 194 ayes to 223 noes, Roll No. 165); and<P/>Takano substitute amendment (No. 9 printed in part A of H. Rept. 115-39) that sought to provide for the suspension and removal of VA employees for performance or misconduct that is a threat to public health and safety in place of the proposed removal process (by a recorded vote of 183 ayes to 232 noes, Roll No. 166).<P/>H. Res. 198, the rule providing for consideration of the bills (H.R. 1259), (H.R. 1367), and (H.R. 1181) was agreed to by a recorded vote of 229 ayes to 187 noes, Roll No. 163, after the previous question was ordered by a yea-and-nay vote of 227 yeas to 185 nays, Roll No. 162.

The House passed H.R. 1259, to amend title 38, United States Code, to provide for the removal or demotion of employees of the Department of Veterans Affairs based on performance or misconduct, by a recorded vote of 237 ayes to 178 noes, Roll No. 168.<P/>Rejected the Kihuen motion to recommit the bill to the Committee on Veterans' Affairs with instructions to report the same back to the House forthwith with amendments, by a recorded vote of 189 ayes to 229 noes, Roll No. 167.<P/>Pursuant to the Rule, an amendment in the nature of a substitute consisting of the text of Rules Committee Print 115-7 shall be considered as an original bill for the purpose of amendment under the five-minute rule.<P/>Walz amendment (No. 2 printed in part A of H. Rept. 115-39) that sought to grant the VA Secretary improved authorities to hold VA senior executives and employees accountable, protects employees' constitutionally guaranteed due process rights, and protects employees' collective bargaining rights under federal law (by a recorded vote of 194 ayes to 223 noes, Roll No. 165); and<P/>Takano substitute amendment (No. 9 printed in part A of H. Rept. 115-39) that sought to provide for the suspension and removal of VA employees for performance or misconduct that is a threat to public health and safety in place of the proposed removal process (by a recorded vote of 183 ayes to 232 noes, Roll No. 166).<P/>H. Res. 198, the rule providing for consideration of the bills (H.R. 1259), (H.R. 1367), and (H.R. 1181) was agreed to by a recorded vote of 229 ayes to 187 noes, Roll No. 163, after the previous question was ordered by a yea-and-nay vote of 227 yeas to 185 nays, Roll No. 162.

The House passed H.R. 1181, to amend title 38, United States Code, to clarify the conditions under which certain persons may be treated as adjudicated mentally incompetent for certain purposes, by a yea-and-nay vote of 240 yeas to 175 nays, Roll No. 169.<P/>H. Res. 198, the rule providing for consideration of the bills (H.R. 1259), (H.R. 1367), and (H.R. 1181) was agreed to by a recorded vote of 229 ayes to 187 noes, Roll No. 163, after the previous question was ordered by a yea-and-nay vote of 227 yeas to 185 nays, Roll No. 162.

The House passed H.R. 1181, to amend title 38, United States Code, to clarify the conditions under which certain persons may be treated as adjudicated mentally incompetent for certain purposes, by a yea-and-nay vote of 240 yeas to 175 nays, Roll No. 169.<P/>H. Res. 198, the rule providing for consideration of the bills (H.R. 1259), (H.R. 1367), and (H.R. 1181) was agreed to by a recorded vote of 229 ayes to 187 noes, Roll No. 163, after the previous question was ordered by a yea-and-nay vote of 227 yeas to 185 nays, Roll No. 162.

The House considered H.R. 1367, to improve the authority of the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to hire and retain physicians and other employees of the Department of Veterans Affairs. Consideration is expected to resume tomorrow, March 17th.<P/>H. Res. 198, the rule providing for consideration of the bills (H.R. 1259), (H.R. 1367), and (H.R. 1181) was agreed to by a recorded vote of 229 ayes to 187 noes, Roll No. 163, after the previous question was ordered by a yea-and-nay vote of 227 yeas to 185 nays, Roll No. 162.

The House considered H.R. 1367, to improve the authority of the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to hire and retain physicians and other employees of the Department of Veterans Affairs. Consideration is expected to resume tomorrow, March 17th.<P/>H. Res. 198, the rule providing for consideration of the bills (H.R. 1259), (H.R. 1367), and (H.R. 1181) was agreed to by a recorded vote of 229 ayes to 187 noes, Roll No. 163, after the previous question was ordered by a yea-and-nay vote of 227 yeas to 185 nays, Roll No. 162.

congVote.result: So the resolution was agreed to.
